thread.title: Leicester boss Claudio Ranieri admits 'gladiators' Millwall deserved FA Cup win
thread.title_full: Leicester boss Claudio Ranieri admits 'gladiators' Millwall deserved FA Cup win

author: James Benge
title: Leicester boss Claudio Ranieri admits 'gladiators' Millwall deserved FA Cup win
text:
28/28 Getty Images 
Leicester manager Claudio Ranieri hailed Millwall’s “fantastic gladiators” after the League One side sent his Premier League champions crashing out of the FA Cup. 
Right-back Shaun Cumming struck in the final minute of normal time to secure a third FA Cup win over Premier League opposition and passage to the sixth round, one game away from Wembley. 
Millwall had been reduced to 10 men early in the second half when Jake Cooper was handed a second yellow for a foul on Ahmed Musa but rallied in the closing minutes. Though they required goalkeeper Jordan Archer to be at his very best they thoroughly merited their late winner, as Ranieri conceded. 
“When they played 10 v 11 they played better than us,” he said. “They had more character, more desire and more heart than us. Millwall 1 Leicester City 0: Lions roar back after red card in FA Cup 
“In the end they deserved to win. They have one chance and they score the goal. Well done to them.” 
The defeat piles further pressure on Ranieri, whose side are battling to stay out of the Premier League relegation zone a year after they were leading the way on their path to a first ever top division league title. 
Ranieri, whose future is likely to come under increased scrutiny after Saturday’s defence, hopes that some good will come from defeat as he looks for his side to rediscover the fighting spirit that took them to the title last season. 
“I need the soldiers, I need the gladiators, because Millwall, with 10 players, showed they are fantastic gladiators. Lincoln's giant-killing inspired Millwall to beat Leicester - Harris 
“It is strange because last season we won for this, to be more determined than the opponent and play with more heart than the opponent. We could also lose but we would fight every match. I want to see this, the fight until the end. 
“This defeat could be good for us because when you lose against a team who fights, you have to say well done to them but why did we lose?” More about:
